title: 108_s1451
content:
The Act is titled the "Runaway, Homeless, and Missing Children Protection Act." It includes amendments to the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act, specifically in Section 302 regarding findings. The Congress recognizes that homeless youth face serious health and safety risks due to lack of resources, leading to law enforcement issues in communities. Many young people urgently need temporary shelter. The Federal Government must address the urgent need for temporary shelter and services for homeless youth, who create law enforcement issues in communities where they gather. It is crucial to develop a national reporting system and effective care system to tackle this interstate problem. The Federal Government is responsible for developing a national reporting system and effective care services for runaway, homeless, and street youth to help them transition successfully to adulthood. Services include preventive and aftercare, emergency shelter, residential shelter, and street outreach. To successfully transition to adulthood, runaway, homeless, and street youth require opportunities for education, job skills training, and employment. Improved coordination among Federal programs serving this population is essential for long-term strategy development. The heading for part A of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to "Basic Center". Grants for services provided under the Act are also addressed. The heading for part A of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to "Basic Center". Section 311(a)(2)(C) is amended to include testing for sexually transmitted diseases at the request of runaway and homeless youth. SEC. 104. REPEAL OF OBSOLETE PROVISION RELATING TO CERTAIN ALLOTMENTS. Amends Section 311(b) of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act by removing obsolete provisions.

SEC. 105. ELIGIBILITY PROVISION. Amends Section 312(a) by replacing "juveniles" with "youth".

SEC. 106. RECOGNITION OF STATE LAW RELATING TO CAPACITY LIMITATION ON ELIGIBLE RUNAWAY AND HOMELESS YOUTH CENTERS. Section 312(a) of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to replace "juveniles" with "youth". Section 312(b)(2)(A) is also amended to include a provision for compliance with state or local laws regarding capacity limitations for youth centers. Additionally, there is a mention of maternity group homes in Section 107. In the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act, eligibility criteria are expanded to include maternity group homes and parenting skills. A new definition for "maternity group home" is provided as a transitional living arrangement for pregnant or parenting youth. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act now includes maternity group homes as transitional living arrangements for pregnant or parenting youth to learn parenting skills and promote long-term economic independence. Limited extension of 540-day shelter eligibility period for youth under 18 years old in the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act program. Youth can remain in the program until their 18th birthday or 180 days after the end of the 540-day period. SEC. 109 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to involve McKinney-Vento school district liaisons in providing educational services to runaway and homeless youth. SEC. 110 addresses coordination agreements in the Act. Section 322(a) of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to include coordination of services with McKinney-Vento school district liaisons to ensure that runaway and homeless youth receive information about educational services. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to include coordination with McKinney-Vento school district liaisons to provide educational services information to runaway and homeless youth. Section 322(a)(7) of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to develop a plan for proper referral of homeless youth to various services such as social services, law enforcement, education, vocational training, welfare, legal services, and health care. SEC. 112 of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act amends Section 341 to ensure coordination of programs for homeless youth by consulting the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. SEC. 113 clarifies grant authority under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act. SEC. 114 makes a technical amendment to demonstration projects. SEC. 115 repeals an obsolete provision related to a study. SEC. 116 sets an age limit for homeless youth. SEC. 115 repeals an obsolete provision related to a study. SEC. 116 sets an age limit for homeless youth not more than 18 years of age seeking shelter in a center under part A. SEC. 117 authorizes appropriations. Section 388(a)(1) and 388(a)(4) of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act are amended to allocate $105,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 and subsequent years. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to allocate funds for fiscal years 2004 and beyond. The amendment includes changes to the allocation percentages for Part B funding. SEC. 118. REPORT ON PROMISING STRATEGIES TO END YOUTH HOMELESSNESS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the United States Interagency Council on Homelessness, must submit a report to Congress on strategies to end youth homelessness within 2 years of this Act. SEC. 119. STUDY OF HOUSING SERVICES AND STRATEGIES. SEC. 119. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will study housing services and strategies for youth exiting programs funded under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act. The study will focus on long-term housing outcomes, available services, placement strategies, and models to prevent future homelessness. SEC. 120. RESTRICTION ON USE OF FUNDS. Amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to prohibit the use of funds for distributing sterile needles for illegal drug injection. Requires separate accounting for funds used for such programs. AMENDMENT TO MISSING CHILDREN'S ASSISTANCE ACT: Section 402 of the Act is amended to update the findings related to missing children. The Congress acknowledges the grave danger faced by abducted children, who are at risk of physical harm and sexual exploitation. Parents and law enforcement often lack resources for extensive search efforts due to children being moved to different locations. Officials lack resources and expertise for expanded search efforts. Abducted children are often moved between localities, requiring cooperation between local, State, and Federal law enforcement. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children serves as a national resource center and works in partnership with various government agencies. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children partners with various government agencies and operates a national and worldwide network to find missing children and prevent child victimization. It links with missing children clearinghouses in all 50 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and Scotland Yard in the United Kingdom. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children operates a worldwide network that links with missing children clearinghouses in all 50 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Scotland Yard, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, and INTERPOL headquarters in Lyon, France. This network allows the Center to instantly transmit images and information about missing children to law enforcement agencies globally. The Missing Children's Assistance Act is amended to authorize appropriations for the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children until 2008. This amendment was passed by the Senate on September 26, 2003. S. 1451 is an act to reauthorize programs under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act and the Missing Children's Assistance Act.
